description.narrative: Management Plan
Communication Project
The project will support the development of a policy and legal environment for effective control of Invasive Alien Species (IAS).

title.narrative: 3013 IAS Project Document Sri Lanka sept 2010final
Invasive Alien Species MTR Report GEF PIMS Final April 28 2
PIMS 3013 Invasive Alien Species 2011 and 2012 PIR
Post-entry risk assessment of Invasive Alien Flora in Sri Lanka: Present status, gap analysis and the most troublesome alien invaders

description.narrative: The project will support the development of policy and legal environment for effective control of Invasvie Alien Species (IAS) including limited field scale models.
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: implemented by the Ministry of Environment, Sri Lanka.

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

1). Number of joint initiatives between Agencies, Private Sector and NGOs formulated through the National Invasive Species Specialist Group & National Focal Point on Invasive Alien Species control 2). Availability of Invasive Alien Species policy and strategy 3). Availability of mechanism to maintain and update the data base on Invasive Alien Spices in Sri Lanka. 4). Invasive Alien Species act is developed for cabinet approval

comment.narrative: 1). Four joint activities implemented through inter-agency participation, with no private sector involvement (2011) Source: project document 2). Working draft of the national Invasive Alien Species policy; working draft of the national Invasive Alien Species strategy and action plan ( 2011) Source: project document 3). National data base is not available for Invasive Alien Species in Sri Lanka. ( 2011) Source: project document 4). No exist for Invasive Alien Species in Sri Lanka ( 2011) Source: project document
1). 5 ( only for this year ) 2). Finalized Policy and Strategy documents available 3). Finalized database and developed mechanism is available 4). Cabinet paper develop on proposed act

1) 5 Joint initiatives established with key stakeholder agencies of the project to conduct IAS baseline assessments. This is the first step to develop and implement pilot projects incorporating ecosystem approach to IAS management 2) IAS National Coordination Committee is functioning with the involvement of key stakeholder agencies. IAS Policy and Strategy has been re-drafted as recommended by the MTR of the project and ready for Cabinet approval. Secretary to the ministry has instructed to include the IAS National Action Plan along with the Policy and Strategy for Cabinet approval. IAS National Action Plan will be finalized within December 2015. National Invasive Species Specialist group was expanded and continuing to provide technical advises. 3) IAS data base is being prepared. Initial arrangements are made ( human and IT resources) to maintain and update the database by national focal point. 4) IAS Act has to be re drafted as recommended by MTR. Process started with the support of a legal consultant and first draft will be available in first quarter of 2016.

1) 10 2) National IAS Policy, Strategy, Action Plan available and approved by the Cabinet. 3) Upgraded IAS Web based data base is up and running. 4) IAS act is prepared and submitted to legal draftsmen department.

1) Eighteen (18) IAS cells have been set up within stakeholder agencies to act as the focal points for implementation of IAS national action plan. Forty (40) district level trainings conducted with the involvement of NGO’s, private firms. Fourteen (14) research grants given to researchers in universities/ research institutions. Eight (8) IAS management pilot projects have been implemented with the support of forest department/wild life conservation department. 2) National IAS Policy, Strategy, Action Plan was approved by the Cabinet and lunched by the H.E. President of Sri Lanka. Awareness built among national, district level on IAS policy. 3) Upgraded IAS web data base has been developed and documents are being uploaded. Officers are available for maintaining the data base. 4) IAS act was prepared and submitted to legal draftsmen department for comments. Few discussions held with legal draftsmen department to address clarifications.

activity-description.narrative: implemented by Ministry of Environment, Sri Lanka

description.narrative: Promoting Sustainable Biomass Energy Production and Modern Bio Energy Technologies. Promotion of the usage of biomass generated energy as a substitute for imported fossil fuels and reduce carbon footprint.

description.narrative: Biomass Energy Production
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: The programme is nationally implemented by the Sustainable Energy Authority and is targeted to benefit whole citizens of Sri Lanka

description.narrative:
Reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from the use of fossil fuel for thermal energy generation in the Sri Lanka industrial sector
Removal of barriers to the realization of sustainable biomass plantation, and adoption of biomass-based energy technologies in Sri Lanka

comment.narrative: Limited experience with BETs in industry;

At least 12 companies are operating BETs and another 12 companies have detailed feasibility studies completed or started installation of gasifier systems by the end of the project (post-project direct emission reduction) in particular gasification with total capacity of 25.7 MWth and 1 MWe, resulting in fossil fuel savings of about 295,178 GJ annually, 4,680 MWh of electricity and direct emission reduction (cumulative over 10 year lifetime) of 252 ktCO2
Indirect emission reduction impacts between 609 (bottom-up) and 1,378 ktCO2 (top down)

There are 10 companies identified as per the inception report (who have pledged co-financing) in relation to the outcome 4. It was expected to add more partners. Of these, three gasifier systems (two Aitken Spence hotels and Apollo Marine International Ltd.) are in operation, and had initiated activities before the project had become operational. The plantation companies listed however are more concerned about implementing fuelwood plantations and improving supply chains. Almost all the tea processing factories listed now use biomass, but for drying purposes, not as gasifiers. The industrial sector (Brandix) has implemented a new plant but not with biomass gasifier. There are six other entities too who were mentioned in the inception report as probable candidates. Of them one company (Lion Brewery) is already considering installing a biomass run plant, but not opting for gasifier technology. However, there are a number of other companies that have already installed and some more have planned to introduce the BET’s for thermal energy requirements during the project period (without project interventions). Majority of them are not Gasifiers as the project has proposed. It is noted that the industry prefers other technologies (direct fired boilers, industrial heaters) over gasifiers to meet their thermal needs. Therefore project needs to review the technology selection to support industry requirements. This concern was highlighted at the project core group meeting as well as the last steering committee meeting, and it was suggested to take up the matter at the MTR time and propose appropriate changes to reflect the changed baseline situation and follow the recommendations therein. With the MTR recommendations, the project is working on updating the activities and Outputs. Subsequently, related indicators will be reflected in the project log frame. Technology related issues will be addressed as well during this adaptive management process. Industry preferences are in biomass fired conventional boilers with modern controlling and feeding systems with co-generation and tri-generation options, industrial dryers, etc. In order to select committed partners for demonstration projects, Project has initiated discussion with the Ceylon Chamber of Commerce (not gone ahead with newspaper advertisement as proposed earlier, as the advertisement by SLSEA for registering supply chain operators received a poor response). Once the technology concern is addressed to project expects to work with the industry on assisting in feasibility studies and technology demonstration.

description.narrative: A set of approved and implemented policy instruments that promote and support the use of sustainably produced fuel wood in industrial thermal applications.
No. of approved and implemented policy instruments that promote and support the use of sustainably produced fuel wood in industrial thermal applications) by EOP

comment.narrative: Various barriers limit in practice the wider-scale application of BETs by industry
One conducive policy-regulatory framework is in place with appropriate incentives for the production, transportation and use of biomass for energy in industrial and commercial establishments

Initial background study on identifying biomass energy related rules regulations and policies conducted.
This will be the base document for the next stages of the activity.

SLSEA is taking action to formalize the cell and its implementation mechanism to accommodate requirements of the new energy policy and the strategy on biomass energy.

comment.narrative: About 18 events

05 events carried out during this period 1. Workshop on development of Provincial Action Plan for Central province - Senior officials from government authorities and provincial level stakeholders (@ Kandy on Dec, 12 & 13, 2014, 84 participants)
2. Workshop on energy productivity improvement
Northern Province - Senior officials from government authorities and provincial level stakeholders (@ Jaffna District Secretariat on Dec 19, 2014, 42 participants)

description.narrative: Number of trained officials by 2016

comment.narrative: 450 national and local-level officials trained
325 officials trained

description.narrative: Output 1.3: Proposed, approved and implemented policies/incentive schemes for fuel switching Policy brief developed on the real cost of fossil fuel subsidy

comment.narrative: Report on pros and cons on fossil fuel subsidies published by year 1, resulting in a at least one policy paper and presentation to Treasury officials through SLSEA

The fossil fuel subsidies existed during project development period has been withdrawn. But there was no firm fossil fuel pricing methodology nor policy governing it in operation, but fuel prices have been brought up as a political issue. Project has been working on obtaining services of a suitable consultant to carry out a study, but this volatile situation was not the opportune time. The establishment of the new government in January 2015, the fossil fuel prices have been changed and the government is planning to introduce transparent, cost reflective pricing formula for fossil fuel as well. Now the country is again at a verge of parliamentary election, through which a new government will be established. The subsidy effect (if any) will be analyzed to take appropriate future actions, when the current scenario is stabilized.

description.narrative: Number of private sector parties actively involved in BEASL by year 5

comment.narrative: 5 Institutional, and 75 individual members
Membership doubled by Year 5 since project inception;

This activity was found to not suit the current context. It will be reviewed post MTR as the project explores possibility of widening the participation of energy sector entities to achieve project outputs. There are other organizations such as Sri Lanka Energy Managers Association (SLEMA), National Cleaner Production Centre (NCPC) that have been identified by the project and recommended by the MTR pane. Therefore, an evaluation of capabilities of all these entities that match with project requirements and getting them involved in delivery is expected.

description.narrative: Long term strategy for biomass energy government established

comment.narrative: No strategy
Strategy and Action Plan endorsed by SLSEA Board by year 3.

SLSEA is very keen on promoting biomass energy technologies and developing a supporting environment for that. Despite the slow progress of the project, SLSEA has been active on biomass energy issues. Post MTR, the Institutional context has been changed now and the SLSEA has been shifted to the Ministry of Power & Energy from the Ministry of Environment. MOPE has recently launched a new energy policy (2015 – 2025) for the country, supported by SLSEA inputs on biomass. This policy has identified activities on biomass energy based on the SLSEA plans including project activities. Hence SLSEA’s long term strategy will be formulated within this context. The project will support SLSEA and MOPE with this work.

description.narrative: Rating of the training events by participants

comment.narrative: 80% rates the training events as good/excellent
Only one of the event of the above 5 (event # 3) is rated. The project will contact the participants 6 months post training to find out the usefulness of the training.

description.narrative: Number of new industries that use biomass as an energy source Incentive schemes for use of fuel wood for energy generation approved by 2016

comment.narrative: At least 12 but target will be set by March 2014. Integrated incentive scheme for biomass-for-energy production and use, implemented by agencies participating in ICRE

No demonstration plants initiated with project inputs as yet. However, there are number of private sector initiatives in place. SLSEA has reported that there are about 180 biomass driven applications are in operation. Project is planning to work with Chamber of Commerce to identify committed plants to demonstrate new technologies beyond the business as usual case. Not initiated yet.

description.narrative: Output 1.4 Existing policies on fuel switch enhanced and implemented. Amounts of loans guaranteed by Sustainable Guarantee Facility (SGF)

comment.narrative: Guarantee facility is operational however restricted to other RE (non-biomass)
Loans to the amount of LKR 400 million are guaranteed by year 5

Sustainable guarantee fund has been established in the SLSEA to provide guarantee facilities to any suitable energy project (both energy efficiency and renewable energy). The project will now work with biomass energy projects who have applied for assistance yet.

description.narrative: Number of applicants to the SGF

comment.narrative: N/A
40 applicants have applied to the fund

No applications pertaining to biomass energy projects have sought assistance of the SGF yet. With the expansion of project activities, more information on SGF to be shared with the intended industry segments.

description.narrative: Enhanced knowledge of and improved support network for sustainable fuel wood production
Hectarage of sustainable fuel wood production

comment.narrative: Hectarage to be determined in surveys
Hectarage needed for supplying demo projects (outcome 4) with fuel wood 2,229 ha established as new plantation models by year 3

The basic arrangements to conduct a biomass resource survey are currently ongoing. Once the survey is concluded in early 2016, the project will be in a position to identify available land to establish demonstration plantations.

description.narrative: Output 2.1: Prepared and disseminated information and knowledge products on fuel wood growing (models) Number of surveys undertaken Publication of handbook on sustainable approaches to biomass growing models

comment.narrative: Info available at NGOs and government by studies undertaken before 2011 0
Surveys conducted in 10 regions on biomass resources, use, land and land use plus survey on current management practices, socio-economic benefits and challenges by 2012. Handbook published by year 1

During a stakeholder consultative workshop, it was decided to conduct a complete survey on biomass resource, use, land and land availability plus survey on current management practices, socio-economic benefits and challenges in 11 districts. These 11 districts were selected based on the supply and demand of the biomass. The duration of the survey will be for 9 months period. The preliminary work is currently ongoing to select a suitable service provider to conduct the survey.
A consultant was hired to provide technical inputs for the survey. Data and information collection process is ongoing to develop the handbook on sustainable approaches to biomass growing models.

description.narrative: Output 2.2: Tested and implemented supportive regulations and policies for sustainable fuel wood production Number of lease procedures published and used by investors Certification scheme of sustainable fuel wood established CCB subsidy revived as a project supported pilot in three districts (Kurunegala, Puttlam, Gampaha) Number of applicants to the scheme Post-project action plan

comment.narrative: 0 0 CCB subsidy suspended due to poor uptake by farmers and high delivery cost to state CCB provides subsidy for gliricidia intercropping N/A

Lease rates, lease procedures and example contracts published by 2015. Certification scheme established by 2014. Disbursement of subsidy by CCB at least 25% of coconut cultivators in three districts. Number of applicants has tripled since project inception by year 5 Post-project action plan formulated by 2015 for replication of the new approaches

A preliminary study on government land approval procedures depending on the ownerships, land lease rates and lease procedures is ongoing to draft the
example lease rates and lease procedures for stakeholder validation. With reference to 2014 PIR, the delayed start of the project was explained and Considering the time factor for developing a certification scheme during the project lifetime, Lead Technical Officer of the project decided to go for a process of developing criteria and indicators for sustainably produced fuel wood. Through a LoA, Sri Lanka Standards Institution (SLSI) was assigned to develop criteria and Indicators for sustainably produce fuel wood. First working group meeting held in May 2015 to draft the initial document. This will be reviewed and updated during the next working group meeting. It is expected to initiate the pilot the scheme by mid-2016. At the time the project was designed, the Coconut Cultivation Board operated a subsidy scheme of LKR 4,000/ac for growing Gliricidia in coconut lands. However, in 2011, this subsidy scheme had been withdrawn due to poor uptake by the farmers. During the Inception Workshop, CCB had agreed to revive a project-supported pilot subsidy scheme for Gliricidia cultivation in the coconut triangle (districts of Gampaha, Kurunegala and Puttalam). There was no follow-up on this initiative, and the CCB had not launched this programme. The project is following up with CCB, who agreed to explore the possibility of incorporating Gliricidia as a component in its animal husbandry subsidy scheme, and to explore ways of mobilizing the communities under the CCB’s Kapruka Societies to enhance Gliricidia cultivation. Not initiated yet.

description.narrative: Output 2.3: Suitable growing models and biomass species for fuel wood production researched and demonstrated in sustainable production demonstrated Improved growing models and identified best growing approaches for suitable fuel wood species Improved and expanded sustainable fuel wood production

comment.narrative: Field trial reports on growing models and at least 3 wood species other than gliricidia The gasifier pilot demonstration projects (Outcome 4) as well as other market demand provided with sufficient sustainably and viably produced fuel wood
Information collection and preliminary studies are ongoing to establish field activities in early 2016 Not yet commenced.

description.narrative: Output 2.4 Completed awareness raising campaigns and specific training programmes for key stakeholders on growing of species for fuel wood production Number of trainings and awareness creating events carried out Rating of training and community level events

comment.narrative: About 40 events held in various places in Sri Lanka with 20 participants each and 120 training days at community level (with 40 participants each); 80% rate workshops and events as good/excellent
Training need assessment is ongoing. It is expected to initiate the training module development by end 2015 and training will commence in 2016. N/A

description.narrative: Improved confidence among industrial and banking sector on the feasibility, stability and economic benefits of sustainable fuel wood supply chains
Number of supply chains developed in a feasible way

comment.narrative: Supply chains meet constraints
At least six supply chains developed that are sustainable on the longer term

The study on the current status of biomass energy has been concluded. This study has recorded that there are well established supply chains feeding industrial zones of Biyagama, Horana and Seethawaka (supplying 820 tons of biomass per day), as well as several large industries located outside industrial zones and tea factories. Fuel is supplied as mainly wood logs, wood chips, and saw dust/rice husk). Several facilities that convert wood logs to chips also established to feed the demand. Prices of different types of fuel and supply mechanisms have been recorded. The major concerns now prevail in the industry are, sustainability of the wood supplies, modes of optimizing existing chains to get the best outcome from the resources involved, and identification of further mechanizations to improve the efficiency of operation and quality of the product. This information will be used to plan future activities in a more focussed manner.
SLSEA has published a newspaper and web advertisement to get supply chain operators listed with them, but received a poor response. However, with the Trainings and awareness activities conducted the project has identified key players. However, smaller grass root level organizations need more attention and that gap will be filled by the Trainers trained at the TOT on supply chain development. SLSEA is planning activities on this regard.

comment.narrative: Enabling policy approved by year 2 and incentive scheme approved by year 3; At least 15 applicants to the scheme by 2016

comment.narrative:
Services of an international consultant on supply chain development has been procured to bring in international experience and exposure and enhance local knowledge base to conduct training in the national level.
Following were conducted with the inputs from him.
1. A 3 day Training of Trainers program for 30 participants - Government stakeholders, university lecturers, industrialists, participants from community level plantation organization (@ Colombo, May 14 -16, 2015, 28 participants) 2. Training workshops for industrialists - Engineers or Managerial level employees with higher diploma or equivalent qualifications, who are involved in biomass supply chain activities in industries (@ Colombo, May 12, 2015, 23 participants) 3. Training workshops for industrialists - Engineers or Managerial level employees with higher diploma or equivalent qualifications, who are involved in biomass supply chain activities in industries (@ Negambo, May 19, 2015, 10 participants) 4. Seminar for policy and financial sectors - Senior/ managerial level employees related to policy, planning and financial sector organizations (@ Colombo, May 21, 2015, 30 participants) Need to evaluate the information. Not commenced yet.

description.narrative: Output 3.3 Six sustainable biomass supply chains established and operational Number of feasibility studies and bankable proposals prepared; Number of biomass supply chains established Information exchange forum established among supply industry

comment.narrative: Ten feasibility studies prepared, of which 8 have resulted in bankable proposals and 6 have started operations Forum established with at least 15 participating members; 6 of which are newly established suppliers by 2016
No feasibility studies commenced as yet. Not commenced yet.

description.narrative: Enhanced knowledge of, access to, and maintenance skills of biomass energy technologies
Number of companies implementing BETs (gasification, fuel switching, EE improvements

comment.narrative:
At least 12 companies implement BETs, directly supported by the project by 2016;
Number of companies all over Sri Lanka that use BETs (t.b.d. in 2 surveys, baseline and end of project)
SLSEA is in the process of collecting baseline information. They have reported that 180 BET plants are reported as at present (excluding Tea sector)

description.narrative: Output 4.1: Twelve implemented, operational and monitored fuel wood thermal energy projects Number of feasibility studies and project designs Number of companies with operational BETs

comment.narrative: 9 companies have expresses willingness to participate (see co-fin letters) 0

About 24 companies have carried out identification and completed feasibility studies by 2017, of which have resulted in operational BETs and improved wood storage in 12 companies. 12 companies have operational BETs by 2017

Not commenced yet Discussions have been initiated with Ceylon Chamber of Commerce to identify suitable demonstration projects The status of demonstration activities under output 4 was described against the project goal, which also based on the same fact. Although the project has mentioned BETs in general, in describing the project goal, there are various technology choices were recommended by the project during the project inception workshop apart from gasifiers alone. However, it was learnt that the industry needs have changed. By taking the advantage of MTR recommendations, the project shall promote various biomass energy technologies (overall goal of CO2 reduction by fuel switching will not affect by the technology choice, as long as the process and the supply of fuelwood is sustainable).
This anomaly needs to be addressed and resolved before engaging the private sector for demonstrations and expected to be resolved at the project consolidation as per the recommendations of MTR. Industry is very keen on biomass energy option and many companies have already installed plants without project inputs. However, project expects to introduce demand driven, modern bio-energy technologies as demonstrations after the conclusion of the project consolidation

description.narrative: Output 4.2: Established information of biomass energy technologies for fuel-switching in industries Technical information provided to potential industries interested in fuel switching Number and amount of investments resulting from the matchmaking and training events

comment.narrative: Manual prepared and disseminated widely through project partners and media, on successful gasification applications and challenges, remedial actions and technical support by 2014 At least 24 companies have taken BET-related investment decisions (in addition to the companies directly supported by the project).

Not initiated yet. Expected to review the technology selection at the project consolidation as per the MTR recommendation. This activity has not been formally commenced. However, there are many companies opting for biomass energy BETs. The project is working on developing partnership with the industry chambers to identify companies that need technical support to implement modern bioenergy technologies and assist them.

description.narrative: Output 4.3: Completed trainings and research aimed at improving services to promote fuel-switching in industry 1) Number of trainings workshops held for staff of companies adopting BET

comment.narrative: At least 10 events, organized with 250 participants in total over 2014- 2017 from technology and service providing companies; At least 80 staff (in particular operators from the participating companies) trained in O&M.

One workshop was conducted by SLSEA, it was well attended and well received by the participants. Workshop was on “Biomass Energy in Industrial Applications” inclusive of a practical session - Engineers or managerial level employees in bulk biomass consuming industries, electricity power plants, university lecturers, government stakeholders (@ MAS Fabric Park, Thulhiriya, Feb 19 -21, 2015, 33 participants).

description.narrative: Output 4.4: Established information exchange system Number of companies that use the database on BET-using industries, national and international technology suppliers and service providers. Performance standard formulated; number of projects that are designed in compliance with the standards.

comment.narrative: SLSEA has taken initial steps to develop the database, data collection and initial discussions with a software development company. Not initiated yet.

policy, planning and administration
Strengthening the Resilience of Post-Conflict Recovery and Development to Climate Change Risks in Sri Lanka
Increase the reslience of communities to climate change through climate smart policies and actions
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: implemented national level through the Gama Neguma and Divi Neguma programmes targeting 12 vulnerable Districts.

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
Increase the resilience of communities to climate change induced hazards through integration of climate smart policies and actions in to development planning and budgeting.

No of sectoral adaptation strategies identified by the project approved and budgeted by the Departments of Agriculture, Agrarian Development, Coastal Conservation and Ministry of Economic Development Climate risk assessment is an integral part of development planning at national and district level

comment.narrative: < 05 climate risk assessment is non-existent

20 strategies and their associated actions implemented Climate risk assessment included in planning processes for VDPs, district development plans and Gama Neguma/Divi Neguma national Programmes in 12 vulnerable districts

It is too early to report the progress against the objective especially because the IP Ministry was dissolved 4 months after the project started. The project was then re-assigned in June 2015, 5 months later.
Nevertheless, during this period the project was able to identify a set of key adaptation actions with relevant government departments.

description.narrative: National rural development programmes Divi Neguma and Gama Neguma integrate climate risk information and adaptation measures in 12 vulnerable districts
No of Gama Neguma and Divi Neguma projects modified through climate risk assessments at GN and Divisional Level

comment.narrative: 150 Gama Neguma Projects. 5 Divi Neguma Strategies including crop selection for home gardens, perennial crops for small commercial farms livestock choice, water and soil management incentives inland/freshwater fishery

Divinaguma programme was influenced to implement adaptive livelihood measures and incorporate climate and disaster resilience into the existing programs. For example, two diversified livelihood development programs (i.e. poultry farming and cattle farming) were promoted in order to minimize dependency on water.

description.narrative: National, district, divisional and local technical staff have sufficient technical capacity to identify and integrate climate risk considerations in designing, approving and implementing development projects under the Gama Neguma and Divi Neguma programmes

Number of staff (disaggregated by gender) within national, district, divisional and local planning units in 12 vulnerable districts reported to apply climate risk assessment tools and methods to new rural investment projects No of stakeholder groups reporting enhanced awareness of climate change risks and adaptation measures at national, district and village levels

comment.narrative:
0 0
(lack of awareness has been reported as a major barrier during stakeholder consultations)

National officers of NPD, MoED, MoF = 20, Technical agencies and department= 50, District Planning and Samurdhi officers= 75, Village Mobilisers= 300, Local Authority Technical Officers =120, Trainers trained =15. Key stakeholder groups listed below report higher level of awareness measured by before and after survey-Officers of National Planning, Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Economic Development- Divi Neguma Task Force at National and District level, District Planning Units, Divisional Planning Units, Village mobilisers-communities in risk prone GN units

The progress against this outcome is low because of the earlier mentioned political issues. However, to date the awareness of 20 government officers from technical agencies and departments (agrarian services department, provincial department of agriculture, Department of veterinary medicine and animal health) was enhanced on climate change adaptation in development planning.

description.narrative: Concrete adaptation actions defined and implemented in selected vulnerable villages/ village clusters in the 12 target districts to increase resilience of rural development programmes to climatic risks

% increase in annual income of farmers (disaggregated by gender) as a result of project introduced adaptation measures implemented in home gardens and small farms
Total value of community driven rural infrastructure built following building codes and construction controls and guidelines for climate and disaster risk reduction

comment.narrative: annual income = or < USD1500 in target farm households 0

15% increase against baseline by 2015 20% increase against baseline by 2016 USD 2.25 million
At least 50% over the baseline value of Gama Neguma Investment in five villages per districts

To date, the project was able to set the ground for implementing climate change adaptation actions by identifying key economic sectors (including minor irrigation and agriculture development) and adaptation priorities.
The project team was able to set the ground for collaborative work between the Department of Agrarian Development and Provincial Department of Agriculture. The project initiated implementation of minor irrigation cascade system development, micro irrigation development and agriculture development. However, some planned activities could not be completed given the dissolution of the Ministry of Economic Development, the identified IP.
